chapter.title: Quick Start
chapter.para: Now that an overview of SymmetricDS has been discussed, a quick working example of SymmetricDS is in order. This section contains a hands-on tutorial that demonstrates how to synchronize a sample database between a client and server engine deployed in a single instance of SymmetricDS. This example models a retail business that has a central office database (called "server") and multiple retail store databases (called "client"). For the tutorial, we will have only one "client", as shown in .

figure.title: Simplified Two Tiered Retail Store Tutorial Example

chapter.para: The server engine captures item data changes for the client, such as item number, description, and price. The client engine captures sale transaction data changes for the server, such as time of sale and items sold. The sample configuration has the client always initiating communication with the server. The client will attach to the server on a periodic basis to pull data from the server. The client will also push captured changes for the server to the server when changes are available.

This tutorial will walk you through:
Installing multiple engines in a single installation of SymmetricDS,
Creating separate databases for the server and client,
Creating sample tables for client and server and sample data for the server,
Starting SymmetricDS and registering the client with the server,
Sending an initial load to the client,
Causing a data push and data pull operation, and
Verifying information about the batches that were sent and received.

section.title: Installing SymmetricDS
section.para: First, we will install the SymmetricDS software and configure it with your database connection information:

step.para: Download the symmetric-ds-3.x.x-server.zip file from http://www.symmetricds.org/
Unzip the file in any directory you choose. This will create a symmetric-ds-3.x.x directory, which corresponds to the version you downloaded.

Copy the following properties files for the server (central office) and client (store) nodes into the engines directory of the SymmetricDS install and edit them to configure the database you want to use.
Set the following properties in both files to specify how to connect to the database:
step.programlisting:
# The class name for the JDBC Driver db.driver=com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
# The JDBC URL used to connect to the database db.url=jdbc:mysql://localhost/sample
# The user to login as who can create and update tables db.user=symmetric
# The password for the user to login as db.password=secret

step.para: Next, set the following property in the client.properties file to specify where the server node can be contacted:
step.programlisting: # The HTTP URL of the server node to contact for registration registration.url=http://localhost:8080/sync/server
step.para: For the tutorial, the client database starts out empty, and the node is not registered. Registration is the process where the node receives its configuration and stores it in its database. The configuration describes which database tables to synchronize and to which nodes. When an unregistered node starts up, it will register with the node specified by the registration URL. The registration node centrally controls nodes on the network by allowing registration and returning configuration. In this tutorial, the registration node is the server node, which also participates in synchronization with other nodes.

section.title: Registering a Node
section.para: Next, we need to open registration for the client node so that it may receive its initial load of data and so that it may receive and send data from and to the server node. There are several ways to do this. We will use the administration feature on the server node.

step.para: Open registration for the client node server by executing:

The registration is now opened for a node group called "store" with an external identifier of "1". This information matches the settings in client.properties for the client node. Each node is assigned to a node group and is given an external ID that makes sense for the application. In this tutorial, we have retail stores that run SymmetricDS, so we named our node group "store" and we used numeric identifiers starting with "1". More information about node groups will be covered in the next chapter.

Watch the logging output of the client node to see it successfully register with the server node. The client is configured to attempt registration once per minute. Once registered, the server and client are enabled for synchronization!

section.title: Pulling Data
section.para: Next, we will make a change to the item data in the central office (we'll add a new item), and observe the data being pulled down to the store.

step.para: Open an interactive SQL session with the server database.
Add a new item for sale:

para.command: insert into item (item_id, price_id, name) values (110000055, 55, 'Soft Drink');

step.para: Once the statements are committed, the data change is captured by SymmetricDS and queued for the client node to pull.
Watch the logging output of both nodes to see the data transfer. The client is configured to pull data from the server every minute.
Verify that the new data arrives in the client database using another interactive SQL session.

section.title: Pushing Data
section.para: We will now simulate a sale at the store and observe how SymmetricDS pushes the sale transaction to the central office.

step.para: Open an interactive SQL session with the client database.
Add a new sale to the client database:

para.command: insert into sale_transaction (tran_id, store, workstation, day, seq) values (1000, '1', '3', '2007-11-01', 100);
insert into sale_return_line_item (tran_id, item_id, price, quantity) values (1000, 110000055, 0.65, 1);

step.para: Once the statements are committed, the data change is captured and queued for the client node to push.
Watch the logging output of both nodes to see the data transfer. The client is configured to push data to the server every minute.

section.title: Verifying Outgoing Batches
section.para: Now that we have pushed and pulled data, we will demonstrate how you can obtain information about what data has been batched and sent. A batch is used for tracking and sending data changes to nodes. The sending node creates a batch and the receiving node acknowledges it. A batch in error is retried during synchronization attempts, but only after data changes in other channels are allowed to be sent. Channels are categories assigned to tables for the purpose of independent synchronization and control. Batches for a channel are not created when a batch in the channel is in error status.

step.para: Open an interactive SQL session with either the server or client database.
Verify that the data change you made was captured:

para.command: select * from sym_data order by data_id desc;

step.para: Each row represents a row of data that was changed. The event_type is "I" for insert, "U" for update", or "D" for delete. For insert and update, the captured data values are listed in row_data. For update and delete, the primary key values are listed in pk_data.
Verify that the data change was routed to a node, using the data_id from the previous step:

When the batched flag is set, the data change is assigned to a batch using a batch_id that is used to track and synchronize the data. Batches are created and assigned during a push or pull synchronization.
Verify that the data change was batched, sent, and acknowledged, using the batch_id from the previous step:

A batch represents a collection of changes to be sent to a node. The batch is created during a push or pull synchronization, when the status is set to "NE" for new. The receiving node acknowledges the batch with a status of "OK" for success or "ER" for error.

section.para: Understanding these three tables, along with a fourth table discussed in the next section, is key to diagnosing any synchronizaiton issues you might encounter. As you work with SymmetricDS, either when experimenting or starting to use SymmetricDS on your own data, spend time monitoring these tables to better understand how SymmetricDS works.

section.title: Verifying Incoming Batches
section.para: The receiving node keeps track of the batches it acknowledges and records statistics about loading the data. Duplicate batches are skipped by default, but this behavior can be changed with the incoming.batches.skip.duplicates runtime property.

A batch represents a collection of changes loaded by the node. The sending node that created the batch is recorded. The status is either "OK" for success or "ER" for error.
